title: Esther Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Esther chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Esther Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Esther Chapter 6.

questions.question: What prevented King Ahasuerus from sleeping on that night?
options: He commanded to bring the book of records to be read
questions.correctAnswer: He commanded to bring the book of records to be read
questions.explanation: Esther 6:1 states that the king could not sleep and commanded the book of records to be brought and read before him.

questions.question: Who were Bigthana and Teresh, mentioned in the king's records?
options: Two of the king's chamberlains who sought to lay hand on the king
questions.correctAnswer: Two of the king's chamberlains who sought to lay hand on the king
questions.explanation: Esther 6:2 explains that Bigthana and Teresh were chamberlains who planned to harm King Ahasuerus.

questions.question: What was the king’s question about Mordecai after reading the records?
options: What honour and dignity hath been done to Mordecai for this?
Why did Mordecai not tell me sooner?
questions.correctAnswer: What honour and dignity hath been done to Mordecai for this?
questions.explanation: In Esther 6:3 the king asks what honor has been done for Mordecai after he saved the king.

questions.question: Who was in the court when the king asked?
questions.correctAnswer: Haman
questions.explanation: Esther 6:4 tells that Haman was in the outward court of the king’s house at that time.

questions.question: What was Haman planning to do to Mordecai when he came into the court?
options: Hang him on the gallows he had prepared
Send him away from the city
questions.correctAnswer: Hang him on the gallows he had prepared
questions.explanation: According to Esther 6:4, Haman came to speak to the king about hanging Mordecai on the gallows he had made.

questions.question: What did the king ask Haman about honoring a man?
options: What shall be done unto the man whom the king delighteth to honour?
How should the man be punished?
questions.correctAnswer: What shall be done unto the man whom the king delighteth to honour?
questions.explanation: Esther 6:6 shows the king asking Haman what honor should be given to the man he wishes to honor.

questions.question: What did Haman suggest should be given to the honored man?
questions.correctAnswer: Royal apparel, horse, and crown
questions.explanation: Esther 6:8 details Haman's suggestion for royal apparel, horse, and crown for the honored man.

questions.question: How was the honored man to be presented to the city according to Haman’s plan?
options: Arrayed in royal apparel, brought on horseback, and proclaimed before him
Carried in a royal chariot with music
Showered with flowers by the people
questions.correctAnswer: Arrayed in royal apparel, brought on horseback, and proclaimed before him
questions.explanation: Esther 6:9 describes the honored man being arrayed, mounted on a horse, and proclaimed through the city streets.

questions.question: Who did the king order to be honored with the royal apparel and horse?
questions.correctAnswer: Mordecai the Jew
questions.explanation: Esther 6:10 states the king ordered that Mordecai be honored in this way.

questions.question: How did Haman feel after he had to honor Mordecai?
options: He went home mourning with his head covered
He made a new plan to punish Mordecai
questions.correctAnswer: He went home mourning with his head covered
questions.explanation: Esther 6:12 describes Haman hurrying home mourning, his head covered.

questions.question: True or False: Mordecai was sitting at the king's gate when he was honored.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Esther 6:10 mentions Mordecai sitting at the king's gate at the time he was honored.

questions.question: True or False: Haman had not prepared gallows for Mordecai before coming to the court.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Esther 6:4 clearly states that Haman had prepared gallows to hang Mordecai.

questions.question: True or False: Zeresh, Haman’s wife, encouraged him that he would prevail against Mordecai.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Esther 6:13 shows Zeresh telling Haman that he would not prevail but fall before Mordecai.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Esther 6:11: 'Then took Haman the apparel and the horse, and arrayed _______, and brought him on horseback through the street of the city.'
questions.correctAnswer: Mordecai
questions.explanation: Esther 6:11 states that Haman arrayed Mordecai and brought him through the city on horseback.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Esther 6:14: 'And while they were yet talking with him, came the king's ________, and hasted to bring Haman unto the banquet that Esther had prepared.'
questions.correctAnswer: chamberlains
questions.explanation: Esther 6:14 mentions the king's chamberlains coming to bring Haman to Esther's banquet.

medium.title: Esther Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Esther Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Esther 6 teach us about the importance of integrity and honesty in the workplace?
options: Mordecai reported a plot against the king, showing faithfulness to authority
Haman was honored for his kindness to Mordecai
The king ignored the records and punished Mordecai
Esther hid the truth about Haman's plan
questions.correctAnswer: Mordecai reported a plot against the king, showing faithfulness to authority
questions.explanation: Esther 6:2 shows Mordecai's honesty in reporting Bigthana and Teresh's plot. This reflects the biblical virtue of integrity in work and respect for authority, as also implied in verses 1 and 3.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged because their faithful service seems unnoticed. Based on Esther 6, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God honors faithful service even if others delay recognition
Only public praise matters to God
One should seek status to prove their value
Recognition is a sign of God's approval
questions.correctAnswer: God honors faithful service even if others delay recognition
questions.explanation: Esther 6:3-4 reveal that Mordecai's good deeds were initially unrewarded, but the king's sleepless night led to his honor. This teaches trust in God's timing and faithfulness, consistent with verses 1 and 10.

questions.question: How does the king’s sleepless night in Esther 6 encourage believers in personal devotion and prayer?
options: God can use unexpected moments to reveal His plans
Prayer is only necessary during the day
questions.correctAnswer: God can use unexpected moments to reveal His plans
questions.explanation: Esther 6:1 shows the king’s sleeplessness leading to reading the chronicles, which uncovered Mordecai’s faithfulness. This encourages believers to trust God’s timing in prayer and devotion, as reflected also in verses 2 and 11.

questions.question: What does Haman’s reaction to being asked about honor teach us about humility?
options: Pride can blind us to God’s plans
We should always seek the highest honor first
questions.correctAnswer: Pride can blind us to God’s plans
questions.explanation: In Esther 6:6, Haman assumes the king would honor him, showing pride. His misunderstanding leads to his own humiliation, teaching humility as a biblical virtue, supported by verses 12 and 13.

questions.question: How does Esther 6 illustrate the value of obedience and following instructions?
options: Haman promptly obeyed the king’s command to honor Mordecai
Mordecai refused to accept the king’s gift
The king ignored the advice of his servants
Haman delayed carrying out the king’s orders
questions.correctAnswer: Haman promptly obeyed the king’s command to honor Mordecai
questions.explanation: Verses 10 and 11 describe Haman quickly obeying the king’s order to honor Mordecai, demonstrating the importance of obedience in daily life, as well as faithfulness to authority (see also verses 5 and 9).

questions.question: A believer struggles with jealousy towards others' success. What biblical truth from Esther 6 would you share?
options: Jealousy can lead to downfall, as seen in Haman’s mourning
Success should be resented in others
God favors only certain people arbitrarily
One’s plans always succeed without God’s involvement
questions.correctAnswer: Jealousy can lead to downfall, as seen in Haman’s mourning
questions.explanation: Esther 6:12 describes Haman mourning and covering his head after honoring Mordecai. This shows how jealousy can cause distress and failure, teaching contentment and humility, supported by verses 13 and 14.

questions.question: True or False: The king’s servants informed him that Mordecai had already been honored for his loyalty.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Esther 6:3 states that the king’s servants declared nothing had been done for Mordecai, indicating a lack of recognition at that time.

questions.question: True or False: Haman was unaware of Mordecai’s identity and background when he was asked to honor him.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Esther 6:13 reveals that Haman knew Mordecai was a Jew and discussed his downfall with his wife and friends, showing awareness of Mordecai’s identity.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: When the king asked what should be done for the man he delights to honor, Haman suggested the man be ___ through the city on horseback.
questions.correctAnswer: proclaimed
questions.explanation: Esther 6:9 describes Haman’s suggestion that the honored man be arrayed in royal apparel and proclaimed through the city, highlighting public honor and recognition.

questions.question: How does Esther 6 demonstrate God’s providence in the life of a believer facing trials?
options: God orchestrates events, even through human decisions, to bring about honor
God ignores believers during their hardships
Human plans are independent of God’s will
questions.correctAnswer: God orchestrates events, even through human decisions, to bring about honor
questions.explanation: The king’s sleeplessness (v1), the reading of chronicles (v2), and the resulting honor of Mordecai (v10-11) illustrate God’s providential care amid trials, supported by verses 3, 6, and 14.

questions.question: What practical lesson about humility and contentment can be drawn from Haman’s experience in Esther 6?
options: Pride leads to unexpected humiliation and sorrow
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to unexpected humiliation and sorrow
questions.explanation: Haman’s pride in assuming he would be honored (v6) leads to his mourning and covered head (v12), teaching humility and contentment, as also seen in verses 13 and 14.

questions.question: How does the interaction between Haman and the king in Esther 6 encourage believers to trust God’s timing rather than their own plans?
options: God’s timing may overturn human schemes for His purpose
Human scheming is more important than faith
God is indifferent to human actions
questions.correctAnswer: God’s timing may overturn human schemes for His purpose
questions.explanation: Haman’s plan to hang Mordecai (v4) is reversed by the king’s order to honor Mordecai (v10), showing God’s sovereign control over events, supported by verses 1, 6, and 11.

questions.question: In Esther 6, what does the public honoring of Mordecai teach about being a witness for God in everyday life?
options: Faithful living can lead to public testimony and encouragement
Faith should be kept private always
Recognition is more important than integrity
questions.correctAnswer: Faithful living can lead to public testimony and encouragement
questions.explanation: Mordecai’s public honor (vv 9-11) exemplifies how obedience and faithfulness can serve as a witness, encouraging believers to live with integrity as in verses 2, 3, and 10.

questions.question: What does the dialogue between Haman and his wife Zeresh in Esther 6 teach about godly counsel and wisdom in times of difficulty?
options: Wise counsel may warn of consequences and encourage humility
questions.correctAnswer: Wise counsel may warn of consequences and encourage humility
questions.explanation: Verse 13 shows Zeresh and Haman’s wise men advising him about his downfall, reminding believers of the value of seeking godly counsel during trials, supported by verses 12 and 14.

questions.question: How does Esther 6 guide believers in dealing with disappointment and unexpected outcomes?
options: Trust God’s purpose even when outcomes differ from expectations
Give up when things don’t go as planned
Revenge is the best response to disappointment
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God’s purpose even when outcomes differ from expectations
questions.explanation: Haman’s plan to harm Mordecai turns into honoring him (vv 11-12), teaching believers to trust God’s sovereign plan amid disappointments, as seen also in verses 3, 6, and 14.

hard.title: Esther Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Esther Chapter 6.

questions.question: What was the reason King Ahasuerus could not sleep on that night?
options: He was troubled by a dream
He wanted to read the chronicles
questions.correctAnswer: He wanted to read the chronicles
questions.explanation: Esther 6:1 indicates the king commanded that the book of records of the chronicles be brought and read before him because he could not sleep.

questions.question: What specific event was recorded in the chronicles that was read to King Ahasuerus?
options: Mordecai saving the king from an assassination plot
questions.correctAnswer: Mordecai saving the king from an assassination plot
questions.explanation: Esther 6:2 describes how Mordecai had reported Bigthana and Teresh, two of the king's chamberlains, who sought to lay hands on the king.

questions.question: What question did King Ahasuerus ask after learning about Mordecai's deed?
options: What honour and dignity has been done to Mordecai for this?
Should Mordecai be made a prince?
questions.correctAnswer: What honour and dignity has been done to Mordecai for this?
questions.explanation: In Esther 6:3, the king asks about the honor and dignity given to Mordecai for his service.

questions.question: Who was present in the court when King Ahasuerus inquired about Mordecai?
questions.correctAnswer: Haman
questions.explanation: Esther 6:4 states that Haman was in the outward court to speak to the king about hanging Mordecai.

questions.question: What was Haman's initial thought when asked what should be done to honor the man the king delights to honor?
options: He thought it was a stranger
questions.correctAnswer: He thought it was himself
questions.explanation: Esther 6:6 reveals Haman thought in his heart that the king would delight to honor him more than anyone else.

questions.question: What royal items did Haman suggest should be given to the man the king delights to honor?
options: A scepter, a throne, and a crown
Royal apparel, the king's horse, and the crown royal
A golden staff, a ring, and royal robes
A palace, servants, and a chariot
questions.correctAnswer: Royal apparel, the king's horse, and the crown royal
questions.explanation: Esther 6:8 details Haman's advice to provide the royal apparel, the king's horse, and the crown royal to honor the man.

questions.question: What instructions did the king give to Haman regarding Mordecai?
options: To give Mordecai a position at court
To honor Mordecai publicly with apparel and horse
questions.correctAnswer: To honor Mordecai publicly with apparel and horse
questions.explanation: Esther 6:10 records the king commanding Haman to do exactly as he suggested, but for Mordecai.

questions.question: How did Haman react after he had honored Mordecai?
options: He rejoiced and made plans to punish Mordecai
He mourned and covered his head
questions.correctAnswer: He mourned and covered his head
questions.explanation: Esther 6:12 shows that Haman went home mourning and with his head covered after the public honor given to Mordecai.

questions.question: What advice did Haman's wife Zeresh and his friends give him regarding Mordecai?
options: That he would surely fall before Mordecai
questions.correctAnswer: That he would surely fall before Mordecai
questions.explanation: Esther 6:13 records Zeresh and the wise men telling Haman he would not prevail against Mordecai but would fall before him.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The two men Mordecai exposed, Bigthana and Teresh, were ______.
options: chamberlains and keepers of the door
questions.correctAnswer: chamberlains and keepers of the door
questions.explanation: Esther 6:2 describes Bigthana and Teresh as two of the king's chamberlains, the keepers of the door.

questions.question: True or False: Haman had already built the gallows for Mordecai's execution before the king's sleepless night.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Esther 6:4 mentions that Haman came to speak to the king to hang Mordecai on the gallows he had prepared.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently displayed in the king honoring Mordecai through Haman, who intended to harm him?
questions.correctAnswer: Irony
questions.explanation: The situation where Haman must honor Mordecai, whom he planned to kill, is an example of situational irony as recorded in Esther 6:10-11.

questions.question: Which Old Testament theme is foreshadowed by Mordecai's vindication in Esther 6?
options: Divine justice and reversal of fortunes
questions.correctAnswer: Divine justice and reversal of fortunes
questions.explanation: The chapter shows a reversal of Haman's plans and the vindication of Mordecai, reflecting the biblical theme of divine justice and reversal found throughout Scripture.

questions.question: How does the role of Mordecai in this chapter connect typologically to Joseph in Genesis?
options: Both are betrayed but rise to honor
Both are priests anointed by God
Both lead Israel to the promised land
questions.correctAnswer: Both are betrayed but rise to honor
questions.explanation: Like Joseph, Mordecai was overlooked and in danger but is publicly honored, showing a typological pattern of God elevating His faithful servants (compare Genesis 37-41).

questions.question: What cultural practice is reflected in the king ordering the honored man to ride on the king's horse and be publicly proclaimed?
options: Ancient Near Eastern royal honor ceremonies
questions.correctAnswer: Ancient Near Eastern royal honor ceremonies
questions.explanation: The public display of honor with royal apparel and horse parallels honor customs common in ancient Near East monarchies, as seen in Esther 6:8-9.

theological.title: Esther Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Esther Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What prompted King Ahasuerus to review the book of chronicles during the night?
options: He wanted to find a new law
questions.correctAnswer: He could not sleep
questions.explanation: Esther 6:1 states that the king could not sleep and commanded the book of records to be read. This reflects God's providential care as seen in Psalm 121:4 and Isaiah 40:28, showing God watches over rulers. The sleeplessness leads to a divine intervention in the narrative, similar to how God used dreams to guide leaders (Daniel 2:1-3).

questions.question: Who were Bigthana and Teresh according to the chronicles read to the king?
options: Two of the king's chamberlains who planned to assassinate the king
Two captains of the king's army
questions.correctAnswer: Two of the king's chamberlains who planned to assassinate the king
questions.explanation: Esther 6:2 identifies Bigthana and Teresh as two chamberlains who sought to lay hands on King Ahasuerus. This illustrates human sin and rebellion against God's ordained authority (Romans 13:1-4), and God's justice in protecting His servant. The theme of divine protection of rulers is echoed in Exodus 1:15-21 and 2 Samuel 15.

questions.question: What question did the king pose after discovering Mordecai's service?
options: What honor and dignity has been done to Mordecai for this?
Who else knows of this event?
questions.correctAnswer: What honor and dignity has been done to Mordecai for this?
questions.explanation: Esther 6:3 shows the king inquiring about the honor given to Mordecai. This highlights God's principle of rewarding faithfulness and good works (Hebrews 11:6, Matthew 6:1-4). It also aligns with biblical justice and recognition found in Proverbs 3:27 and Luke 6:35.

questions.question: What was Haman's original intention when he entered the king’s court?
options: To ask for permission to hang Mordecai
questions.correctAnswer: To ask for permission to hang Mordecai
questions.explanation: Esther 6:4 reveals Haman’s intent to speak to the king about hanging Mordecai. This demonstrates human pride and self-reliance opposed to God's sovereignty (Proverbs 16:18, James 4:6). The narrative shows God’s providence overturning evil plans as in Joseph’s story (Genesis 50:20).

questions.question: How did King Ahasuerus respond when he saw Haman in the court?
options: He told the servants to bring Haman in
He asked Haman to wait outside
questions.correctAnswer: He told the servants to bring Haman in
questions.explanation: Esther 6:5 states that the king ordered Haman to come in. This sets the stage for divine irony where human plans are subverted by God's providence (Proverbs 19:21, Romans 8:28). It echoes God's sovereignty in human affairs (Daniel 4:35).

questions.question: What did the king ask Haman concerning the man he delights to honor?
options: What shall be done unto the man whom the king delighteth to honour?
Who is this man you speak of?
Why do you want to honor him?
questions.correctAnswer: What shall be done unto the man whom the king delighteth to honour?
questions.explanation: Esther 6:6 presents the king’s question about honoring a man. This moment highlights God's use of earthly authority for His purposes (Romans 13:1) and the reversal of human pride (1 Corinthians 1:27-29). It teaches that true honor comes from God who controls the hearts of rulers.

questions.question: What did Haman propose should be done for the man the king delights to honor?
options: Let the royal apparel be brought, the horse the king rides, and the royal crown
Give him a large sum of money
Make him a prince of the kingdom
Build a statue in his honor
questions.correctAnswer: Let the royal apparel be brought, the horse the king rides, and the royal crown
questions.explanation: Esther 6:7-8 shows Haman's detailed proposal of royal honors. This reflects the biblical theme of honor as a public testimony of God’s blessing (1 Samuel 16:7, Matthew 23:12). Ironically, Haman’s pride blinds him to the true recipient, demonstrating the folly of self-exaltation (Luke 14:11).

questions.question: Who was actually honored with the royal apparel and horse according to the king’s command?
questions.correctAnswer: Mordecai the Jew
questions.explanation: Esther 6:10-11 records that Mordecai was honored, not Haman. This shows God's providential protection of His people and vindication of righteousness (Psalm 37:23-24, Romans 8:31). It anticipates Christ’s exaltation after suffering (Philippians 2:9-11).

questions.question: How did Haman react after Mordecai was honored?
options: He went home mourning, with his head covered
He rejoiced and praised the king
questions.correctAnswer: He went home mourning, with his head covered
questions.explanation: Esther 6:12 describes Haman’s mourning and shame, which illustrates the consequences of pride and evil intentions opposed to God’s will (Proverbs 16:18, James 4:10). This serves as a warning against self-exaltation and resistance to God’s righteous plans.

questions.question: What counsel did Haman’s wife Zeresh and his friends give him after hearing what happened?
options: If Mordecai is of Jewish descent, you will surely fall before him
You should ask the king for mercy
questions.correctAnswer: If Mordecai is of Jewish descent, you will surely fall before him
questions.explanation: Esther 6:13 shows Zeresh and friends' prophetic warning, highlighting God's sovereign plan for His covenant people (Genesis 12:3, Romans 11:28-29). It underscores the theme of divine election and the ultimate triumph of God’s people (Isaiah 41:10).

questions.question: What event interrupted Haman’s conversation with his wife and friends?
options: The king's chamberlains came to bring him to Esther's banquet
A royal messenger announced a decree
questions.correctAnswer: The king's chamberlains came to bring him to Esther's banquet
questions.explanation: Esther 6:14 records that the king’s chamberlains came to bring Haman to the banquet Esther had prepared. This event reveals God’s timing and orchestration of events (Ecclesiastes 3:1, Acts 1:7), showcasing divine providence in salvation history.

questions.question: How does the king’s sleepless night in Esther 6 demonstrate God’s providential care?
options: God used the sleeplessness to bring justice to Mordecai
It was a punishment for the king’s sins
It was unrelated to the events of the chapter
It caused the king to abdicate
questions.correctAnswer: God used the sleeplessness to bring justice to Mordecai
questions.explanation: The sleepless night (Esther 6:1) is a divine intervention to bring about justice, consistent with God's providential governance (Psalm 127:2, Proverbs 21:1). It parallels Joseph’s story where God uses circumstances to fulfill His purposes (Genesis 41:9-16).

questions.question: What theological theme is demonstrated by the king honoring Mordecai instead of Haman?
options: God’s reversal of human pride and exaltation of the humble
questions.correctAnswer: God’s reversal of human pride and exaltation of the humble
questions.explanation: The honor given to Mordecai over Haman (Esther 6:10-11) illustrates the biblical principle of God humbling the proud and lifting the humble (Luke 1:52, James 4:6). This theme is central to biblical theology and Christ’s own exaltation (Philippians 2:5-11).

questions.question: What does Haman’s mourning and covering of his head symbolize in the biblical context?
options: Shame and humiliation before God and man
questions.correctAnswer: Shame and humiliation before God and man
questions.explanation: Haman’s mourning and head covering (Esther 6:12) symbolize deep shame, as head covering was often a sign of disgrace (Jeremiah 13:18, 1 Corinthians 11:4). It reflects the consequences of sin and rebellion against God’s righteous decrees (Proverbs 11:2).

questions.question: How does the advice given by Zeresh and Haman’s friends reflect God’s sovereignty over the nations?
options: They acknowledge that God’s people will ultimately prevail
They recommend Haman flee the kingdom
They advise Haman to increase his power
questions.correctAnswer: They acknowledge that God’s people will ultimately prevail
questions.explanation: Zeresh and friends' counsel (Esther 6:13) recognizes the divine protection and destiny of God's people, consistent with God's promises in Isaiah 43:1-3 and Romans 8:31. This illustrates God’s control over the rise and fall of nations (Daniel 2:21).
